title: Pillsike
author: Pillsike
content: Okay so earlier I came across a site that claimed that it's possible to get bitcoins for free by just; playing offline and online games, watching ads and videos, participating in airdrops and so on. They also recommended apps that give out bitcoin for free Â like coinbase. Bitcoin, ranked as one of the most expensive cypto currencies can be earned for free by just watching ads? Nah I just find it hard to believe cause I've seen a lot of scam related schemes that claim to give out bitcoin for free. I don't know, I might be wrong cause I'm still a newbie that's why I brought this here, to see if I can get some clarification on the matter. Thank you.

comments.author: OmegaStarScream
comments.created_time: November 26, 2022, 06:30:48 AMLast edit: November 26, 2022, 07:18:56 AM by OmegaStarScream
comments.body: Possible? yes. Is it worth your time? probably not.The same thing applies to Coinbase[1] and other similar programs[2]. Some of them require you to verify your identity before you can claim the rewards which is something I don't recommend doing.[1] https://www.coinbase.com/learning-rewards[2] https://www.okx.com/freebitcoin

comments.author: UserU
comments.body: Faucets are like the OG.Adding to what Omega said, back in the days when BTC was still in its infancy, they used to dispense large amounts which meant big banks if you held on them and never sold.Now realistically, it's not always about earning Bitcoin, rather using fiat to buy Bitcoin. Both concepts are the same because Bitcoin is measured by its fiat value. Using the faucet example, the values per claim have mainly been in cents but BTC was only valued in cents as well. Now you'd only get like single-digit satoshis and a bunch of ads right in your face. And those courses from exchanges like Binance that give free crypto seldom teach on moving your funds to a cold wallet. If they get hacked one day, the cryptos you supposedly earn become mere numbers.For instance, if you were to complete a job that pays $20 in Bitcoin, at the current rate of $16,550, that's ~0.0012 BTC. Some fees are lost over conversion and network/ blockchain but they're like mere cents to a few dollars at most.

I haven't participated in any airdrop in the last few year, haven't heard any airdrop to give a good amount too. Anything you are looking for free, is a waste of time these days.

comments.author: Daniel91
comments.body: If the question is whether you can get bitcoin for free, without doing anything, the answer is no, that is, there are some ways, like faucets, but they are not profitable.You can buy Bitcoin with your own money, get it by trading or earn it by concrete work.You can never get something for nothing.However, I advise you to look under market and services on this forum for ways to earn bitcoin based on specific work such as logo creation, translation, signature campaigns etc.Through simple work, you can earn bitcoins without the risk of investing your own money. You might be interested in that.

comments.author: examplens
comments.body: OP, you need to know some facts about "free" bitcoin. Most often it is a miserable amount, but if you are a beginner, it is a very good way to get better acquainted with the way the network works. You will learn more about transactions, public and private keys, tx fees etc...in case you come across an offer that offers a much larger amount for free, be sure that it is a scam or a false offer.Quote from: mk4 on November 26, 2022, 11:17:03 AMIt's not "free" though, isn't it? Not because something takes little effort doesn't mean it's free. You're still wasting precious time that you could be using for something else far more productive.many do not consider their time as a valuable resource, although it is quite limited.I guess anything can be considered free as long as you don't have to take money out of your wallet.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Quote from: mk4 on November 26, 2022, 11:17:03 AMIt's not "free" though, isn't it? Not because something takes little effort doesn't mean it's free. You're still wasting precious time that you could be using for something else far more productive.Many people don't consider investing their time as an investment, I think the OP is primarily thinking about how to get BTC without investing fiat. I agree that faucets and various PTCs are very slow and poorly paid ways to earn BTC, although some would be surprised if this was the case in the past when BTC was only worth a few hundred $. Faucets used to pay 1000 to 5000 satoshi per claim, currently they pay 1-15 sat per claim, but the fiat value of those coins has not changed too much.What apparently no one takes into account is that these questions are mostly asked by very young people who cannot yet do anything "productive" nor can they legally buy BTC because they are underage. Sometimes it may be better to spend a little time on something than to invest directly, and besides, there are much worse ways to waste time, such as watching TV or playing games, which have become the daily routine of a large number of young people.

comments.author: decodx
comments.body: I think faucets are not worth your time. I mean, because the chances of them paying out is quite low. You will have to wait for months before you reach their minimum payout threshold. I think we, who are always looking for ways to earn more bitcoins should also bear in mind that time is the most precious resource in all of this, hence using our time on faucets is not the best thing to do. So the conclusion is: yes it's possible to get free bitcoins but only in small amounts. If you're up for spending a lot of time accomplishing this, then go for it, if you don't have the time, then it's not worth it.
